Award.AwardTitle: A PLASMON-ENHANCED TEMPERATURE-SWING PROCESS FOR CONVERSION OF CARBON DIOXIDE TO CARBON MONOXIDE

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kuhn, John
Proposal Number: 1335817
Institution: University of South Florida
Title: A Plasmon-enhanced Temperature-swing Process for Conversion of Carbon Dioxide to Carbon Monoxide

This project examines a novel photochemical route for the transformation of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and oxygen. The primary research goals are (1) to discover perovskite-type oxides with a large change in oxygen content (delta) for small changes in temperature in a low temperature range (T=350 to 400 deg. C), (2) to design and demonstrate monometallic silver and bimetallic silver-based particles that have peak plasmonic absorption wavelengths across the visible light spectrum resulting in a maximum temperature increase, (3) to identify the catalytic consequences of the composite materials (Ag-based phase supported on the perovskite-type oxides) on the molecular processes associated with carbon dioxide conversion and oxygen generation, and (4) to validate the predicted behaviors of prepared materials in photo-induced temperature swing separation and conversion of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide.

This project will advance the field of carbon management as well as topics of optical properties of metal nanoparticles, design of mixed metal oxides, and synergy between these two sets of materials. The project will merge the experimental and computational aspects in both the research and in the student training. Carbon dioxide emissions are an imminent and global problem and the proposed effort could significantly impact the status quo. The project will also contribute to the focus on sustainability and energy research and teaching at USF through a multi-pronged endeavor of activities with an emphasis on building students with both experimental and computational experiences and skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project is to demonstrate a novel thermochemical approach for sustainable conversion of carbon dioxide to hydrocarbon fuels. Currently, fossil-fuel-fired power plants exhibit huge emissions of carbon dioxide and availability of sequestration capacity is not enough to account for all carbon dioxide generated. The efforts of this project substantiate progress towards sustainable repurposing of this waste carbon dioxide, rather than storage, for the generation of useful chemicals and fuels. Carbon monoxide is a platform feedstock for the synthesis of chemicals and fuels and technologies with potential for large scale, but conversion of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide is the most challenging step. The outcome of this project has successfully addressed this issue, demonstrating carbon dioxide conversion at low temperatures with highest carbon monoxide production rates. The broader impact of this project thereby translates to solving carbon dioxide mitigation problem along with closing a synthetic carbon cycle that forms the backbone/core of our energy resources and global economy.

 

The process and materials developed from this project have the potential to capture this waste carbon dioxide and repurpose it towards generation of hydrocarbon fuels and other high value hydrocarbons. The process, reverse water gas shift chemical looping (RWGS-CL) has demonstrated capability of converting carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide at high rates and at low temperatures, paving the way for implementation at large scale. The temperatures of operation of RWGS-CL allows for thermal integration with Fischer Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) and/or methanol synthesis. The process is designed such that there is no intermixing of carbon monoxide and water or hydrogen, thereby restricting any methane formation or any backward reaction (WGS). The process has been demonstrated for several cycles without loss of activity due to the selection of robust materials.

 

The primary materials advances made through this effort are the: (1) discovery of perovskite-type oxides with a large change in oxygen content for small changes in temperature for a low temperature range (~500 °C); (2) design and demonstration of silver-based particles that have peak plasmonic absorption wavelengths across the visible light spectrum; (3) identification of catalytic consequences of selected materials on the molecular steps associated with the conversion process; and (4) validation of selected materials for the conversion of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide. A suite of materials with varied composition have been computationally predicted and experimentally validated to achieve isothermal cycling at temperatures of 500 to 600 °C, which is very low compared to many thermochemical conversion strategies. Promising formulations were further tuned to maximize performance. Carbon dioxide conversion reactions on the surface of these perovskite oxides (ABO3) are significantly dominated by two parameters: structural and electronic properties of the surface and the oxygen vacancy formation energy of the material. Detailed surface investigation was conducted on a series of perovskite oxides to provide insights on the electronic properties and oxygen vacancy formation characteristics across different facets (eg. <100> and <110>) having varying surface terminations. Oxygen vacancy formation energies for these mixed perovskite oxides are found to be a function of the ‘A’ site and ‘B’ site compositions and the findings were corroborated experimental efforts. This intrinsic material property, oxygen vacancy formation energy, was thus used to screen a vast material space to predict materials having desired carbon dioxide conversion capacities. Carbon dioxide adsorption strength, a key descriptor for carbon dioxide conversion reactions, is found to increase on oxygen vacant surfaces thus establishing the importance of oxygen vacancies in carbon dioxide conversion reactions. Several metal-based phases were evaluated for plasmonic and catalytic effects. The use of the plasmonic materials in reactor design (not as a co-catalyst) using Ag and Pd-Ag particles was established as a new methodology.
